title: 106_s1468
content: The Act may be cited as the "United States Capitol Visitor Center Commemorative Coin Act of 1999". Congress finds that the Capitol building in Washington, D.C. is a significant symbol of democracy, attracting millions of visitors annually. The building lacks necessary facilities for visitors, but has excellent security provided by the United States Capitol Police. Congress has allocated $100,000,000 for improvements. Congress has appropriated $100,000,000, supplemented with private funds, to construct a Capitol Visitor Center for high security and visitor education. Congress offers the opportunity for voluntary fundraising for the center and authorizes coins to commemorate the first convening of Congress in the Capitol building. Proceeds from coin sales will be deposited for the United States Capitol Preservation Commission. The $100,000,000 appropriated by Congress, along with private funds, will be used to construct a Capitol Visitor Center for security and education. Proceeds from coin sales will be deposited for the United States Capitol Preservation Commission to aid in construction and maintenance. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue bimetallic $10 coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific specifications. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue bimetallic $10 coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific specifications. Additionally, if bimetallic coins are not feasible, the Secretary may mint up to 100,000 $5 gold coins weighing 8.359 grams, with a diameter of 0.850 inches, and containing 90 percent gold and 10 percent alloy. The coins minted under this Act contain 90 percent gold and 10 percent alloy, and shall be legal tender. Waivers for mintage levels can be granted as per section 5112(m)(2)(B) of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary shall obtain platinum, gold, and silver from available sources for minting coins under this Act. Design requirements for coins minted under this Act include being emblematic of the first meeting of the United States Congress in the United States Capitol Building, with inscriptions of value, year, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design selection process is also specified. The design for coins minted under this Act will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the United States Capitol Preservation Commission, the Commission of Fine Arts, and the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The Secretary will select the design for coins minted under this Act in consultation with various committees. The coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, with only one facility of the United States Mint used for each denomination and quality combination. These coins will be the first commemorative coins of the United States to bear the year "2000" inscription, and the Secretary will consult with the Commission for promotion and marketing. The Secretary may commission the promotion, advertising, and marketing of coins minted under this Act. If deemed beneficial, a contract may be entered into with the Commission or another entity for this purpose. SEC. 7. SALE OF COINS. The coins minted under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, the surcharge provided in subsection (d), and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted before the coins are issued. The Secretary will sell coins minted under this Act at face value plus a surcharge established by the Secretary. Bulk sales will be discounted, and prepaid orders will be accepted before issuance. Surcharges for different coin denominations are specified. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales will be deposited in the Capitol Preservation Fund for the construction and maintenance of a Capitol Visitor Center.
